importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: Eurostar plans to start using the first six double-decker trains in 2031, marking a significant milestone in its expansion timeline.
The article was published on this date, announcing the official confirmation of Eurostar's double-decker train order and related plans.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The implementation of the new double-decker trains is scheduled to begin in 2031, following a multi-year development and certification process.

keyTakeAways: Eurostar has ordered 30 'Celestia' double-decker trains from Alstom, with the option for 20 more, representing a 30% increase in its fleet.
The trains will be 200 meters long and, when paired, will offer a total of about 1,080 seats, marking the first time double-decker high-speed trains will operate through the Channel Tunnel.
The expansion includes significant investment in the Temple Mills depot in London, which is the only UK depot capable of accommodating the larger trains.
The trains will undergo a multi-year certification process across all Eurostar-operating countries due to safety and technical standards.
Each train will be 4.33 meters high—just 16 cm taller than current E320 models—minimizing compatibility issues with existing infrastructure.

Despite the innovation, experts like Pete Waterman argue that widespread adoption of double-deckers across the UK rail network is unlikely due to age and structural limitations of the existing infrastructure.
The expansion comes after Eurostar's June 2025 plan to launch new routes to Geneva and Frankfurt from London.
The Office of Rail and Road is reviewing access to the Temple Mills depot, as rival operators like Evolyn, Virgin, and Gemini Trains–Uber seek to operate there as well.

namedEntities.name: Eurostar
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A cross-Channel rail operator providing high-speed services between London and Paris, and other European cities.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Eurostar is central to the article as the company announcing and implementing the first double-decker trains through the Channel Tunnel.

namedEntities.name: Alstom
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A global transportation technology company that manufactures trains and rail systems.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Alstom is the train manufacturer selected by Eurostar for the production of the new 'Celestia' double-decker trains.

namedEntities.name: Celestia
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A new model of double-decker high-speed train being developed by Alstom for Eurostar.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Celestia trains represent the core innovation of the article, being the first double-deckers to operate through the Channel Tunnel.

namedEntities.name: Temple Mills depot
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A rail depot in London, owned by the London St Pancras Highspeed organisation, currently used exclusively by Eurostar.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The depot is critical for housing and maintaining the new double-decker trains and is the only UK facility capable of accommodating them.

namedEntities.name: Pete Waterman
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A music producer and train enthusiast who has commented on the feasibility of double-decker trains in the UK.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Pete Waterman provides expert insight into the structural and infrastructural challenges of introducing double-deckers across the UK network.

namedEntities.name: Evolyn
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A Spanish start-up company proposing to offer cross-Channel rail services from London to continental Europe.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Evolyn is cited as a potential rival to Eurostar, raising competition over access to the Temple Mills depot.

namedEntities.name: Virgin
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A brand under Sir Richard Branson's ownership that has expressed interest in entering the cross-Channel rail market.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Virgin is identified as a competitor to Eurostar, contributing to the competitive environment over depot access and market share.

namedEntities.name: Gemini Trains
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A train operator in partnership with Uber that is proposing to offer cross-Channel rail services.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Gemini Trains–Uber is named as a potential rival, highlighting concerns over access to the Temple Mills depot and market competition.

namedEntities.name: Office of Rail and Road
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The UK government regulatory body overseeing rail infrastructure and access policies.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Office of Rail and Road is reviewing access to Temple Mills and is expected to issue a decision on depot usage within weeks.

namedEntities.name: Channel Tunnel
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A rail tunnel connecting the UK and France, used by Eurostar for cross-Channel services.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Channel Tunnel is the key transit route through which the new double-decker trains will operate for the first time.

namedEntities.name: Gwendoline Cazenave
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Chief executive of Eurostar, who publicly announced the double-decker initiative.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: She is quoted as expressing pride and confidence in the new trains, emphasizing passenger comfort and growth goals.

namedEntities.name: E320
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Current model of high-speed train used by Eurostar in the UK.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The new double-deckers are slightly taller (16 cm) than the E320 models, indicating a careful engineering adjustment to maintain compatibility.

namedEntities.name: London St Pancras Highspeed organisation
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A government-owned entity that owns the Temple Mills depot.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: This organisation owns the only depot in the UK suitable for Eurostar’s new double-decker trains and is central to the expansion plan.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Eurostar has announced a major expansion by ordering up to 50 double-decker 'Celestia' trains from Alstom, with the first six scheduled to enter service in 2031. This marks the first time double-decker high-speed trains will operate through the Channel Tunnel, offering about 1,080 seats when two trains run together. The new trains will be slightly taller than current models, and will require extensive certification across all Eurostar operating countries. The expansion includes a €80 million investment in the Temple Mills depot in London, the only UK facility capable of housing the larger trains. While Eurostar aims to grow its passenger numbers from 19.5 million to 30 million, experts such as music producer Pete Waterman warn that widespread adoption of double-deckers across the UK rail network is unlikely due to outdated infrastructure. Meanwhile, rival operators including Evolyn, Virgin, and a Gemini Trains–Uber partnership are seeking access to the Temple Mills depot, prompting the Office of Rail and Road to review access policies.
title: Eurostar orders first double-decker trains
